A Linear Pair is a pair of adjacent angles whose non-common sides form a straight Line. Linear pairs are always supplementary (sum to 180°).
A Point can be located by (r, θ) where r is the distance from the origin and θ is the Angle from the positive x-axis.
A biconditional statement (p ↔ q) means "p if and only if q." It is true when both p and q have the same truth value.
A common rule: a value is an outlier if it is below Q1 − 1.5 × IQR or above Q3 + 1.5 × IQR.
A conditional statement has the form "If p, then q" (written p → q). The hypothesis is p and the conclusion is q.
A dilation centered at Point O with scale factor k maps every Point P to a Point P' such that OP' = k × OP.
A figure has point symmetry if a 180° rotation maps it onto itself. This is rotational symmetry of order 2.
A figure has rotational symmetry if a rotation of less than 360° maps the figure onto itself. The smallest such angle is the angle of rotational symmetry.
A one-step equation requires a single operation to solve. Use inverse operations: addition ↔ subtraction, multiplication ↔ division.
A quadratic function has the form y = ax² + bx + c. Its graph is a parabola.
A quadratic inequality has the form ax² + bx + c > 0 (or <, ≤, ≥).
A rational exponent a^(m/n) = ⁿ√(aᵐ) = (ⁿ√a)ᵐ.
A recursive formula defines each term based on the previous term(s): a(n) = a(n−1) + d (arithmetic) or a(n) = a(n−1) · r (geometric).
A regular n-gon has rotational symmetry of order n. The smallest rotation Angle that maps it onto itself is 360°/n.
A residual is the difference between an observed value and the predicted value: residual = observed − predicted.
A sector is a "pie slice" of a circle defined by a central angle θ.
A step function is a piecewise function where each piece is a constant (horizontal segment). The greatest integer function ⌊x⌋ is a common example.
A translation slides every point of a figure the same distance in the same direction. It is described by a vector ⟨a, b⟩.
A translation vector ⟨a, b⟩ indicates a horizontal shift of a units and a vertical shift of b units.
A vector is a quantity that has both magnitude (size) and direction. Represented as an arrow or in component form <a, b>.
A(segment) = A(sector) − A(triangle)
AND means the solution must satisfy both inequalities (intersection). Example: −2 < x < 5.
AP Connections: Higher-degree polynomials appear in optimization in calculus. Taylor series approximate functions using polynomials. Interpolation fits n points with degree n-1 polynomial.

AP Connections: Linear programming and system optimization appear in AP Calculus as constrained optimization and Lagrange multipliers. Understanding these foundations is essential for advanced mathematics.

AP Connections: Mathematical induction foundation for many calculus proofs and theorem verification. Recursive functions and sequences central to analysis. The principle of induction connects to the completeness axiom in real number system, essential for rigorous calculus development.

AP Connections: Natural exponential and logarithm are the fundamental functions in calculus. d/dx(e^x) = e^x and d/dx(ln x) = 1/x. Integration of 1/x gives ln|x|. Taylor series for e^x, sin(x), cos(x) appear throughout calculus.

AP Connections: Rational functions appear in optimization problems (minimize cost, maximize profit). L'Hôpital's Rule in calculus uses these to evaluate limits. Partial fraction decomposition is used for integration.

AP Connections: Regression inference (confidence intervals, hypothesis tests) are central to AP Statistics. Understanding sampling distributions of estimators connects to calculus-based probability and limits. LOWESS regression and smoothing lead to advanced statistical methods.

AP Connections: Trigonometric functions are periodic. Derivatives: d/dx(sin x) = cos x, d/dx(cos x) = -sin x. Integration of sin/cos appears throughout calculus. Exponential and trig connection via Euler's formula: e^{iθ} = cos θ + i sin θ.
Add/Subtract radicals: only combine like radicals (same radicand). Example: 3√5 + 2√5 = 5√5.
Adding Polynomials: Combine like terms (same variable and exponent). Arrange terms in descending order. Group coefficients of each power separately.

Adding and Subtracting: Find a common denominator (usually the LCD). Rewrite each fraction. Add/subtract numerators; denominator stays the same. Simplify the result. Include domain restrictions from both original expressions.
Advantages: Elimination is more efficient when coefficients are large or when substitution creates messy fractions. It avoids the need to isolate variables first.
Algebraic Methods: Prepare to learn substitution and elimination methods in the next lessons. Both methods transform the system to isolate variables and find the solution.
Algebraic Techniques: Factor: sin x cos x - sin x = 0 → sin x (cos x - 1) = 0. Quadratic formula: 2 sin² x - sin x - 1 = 0 using substitution u = sin x. Use identities to simplify before solving.
All these linear ratios equal the scale factor k. Areas are in the ratio k².
Always check for extraneous solutions — solutions that make a denominator zero are not valid.
Always check for extraneous solutions — squaring can introduce false solutions.
Always describe distributions in context — relate numbers back to what the data represents.
Always factor first — cancellation only works with factors, not terms.
An Angle is formed by two rays with a common endpoint called the vertex. The rays are called the sides of the Angle. Angles are measured in degrees (°).
An exponential decay function has the form f(x) = a · bˣ where a > 0 and 0 .
An exponential growth function has the form f(x) = a · bˣ where a > 0 and b > 1.
Analyzing Behavior: Near vertical asymptote, function approaches +∞ or -∞ depending on sign of denominator from left/right. Test points on either side to determine which direction.
Angle Between Vectors: cos θ = (u·v)/(|u||v|). Orthogonal (perpendicular) vectors: u·v = 0. Parallel vectors: one is scalar multiple of other. Component of u along v: (u·v)/|v|.
Antimatter: Every particle has an antiparticle (same mass, opposite charge). When they meet: annihilation → pure energy.
Application Extensions: Complex mixture problems with three or more substances. Optimization problems with multiple constraints and real-world parameters.

Applications: Exponential growth/decay (bacteria, investments). Fractals and self-similar structures. Bouncing ball problems (heights form geometric sequence). Depreciation: asset value decreases by constant percentage.
Applications: Kepler's third law is used to determine the masses of stars and planets, and to predict orbital parameters of satellites.
Applications: Linear patterns in data. Counting: total items in stepped arrangement. Time intervals: events at regular intervals. Savings plans: deposit fixed amount each period.
Applications: Medical diagnosis: likelihood of disease given test result. Quality control: probability defective given supplier. Database queries: probability matching criteria given constraints.
Applications: Passwords: each position could be different letter/digit. Seating arrangements. Top finishers in race. Anagrams of words (with and without repeated letters).

Applications: Projectile motion: x(t) = v₀cos θ·t, y(t) = v₀sin θ·t - ½gt². Cycloid: x = r(t - sin t), y = r(1 - cos t). Parametric curves used extensively in physics and calculus for motion analysis.
Applications: Radioactive decay: N(t) = N_0 e^{-μt}. Half-life calculation when N(t) = N_0/2. pH in chemistry: pH = -log[H⁺]. Earthquake magnitude: M = log(I/I_0).
Applications: Repeating decimals to fractions. Fractal areas and lengths (Koch snowflake). Loan and mortgage calculations using present value. Annuities and perpetuities in finance.
Apply each rule in sequence. For example, a rotation of 90° CCW followed by a reflection over the x-axis: (x, y) → (−y, x) → (−y, −x).
Arc length = (θ/360°) × 2πr
Arithmetic Sequence: Sequence with constant difference d between consecutive terms. a_n = a_1 + (n-1)d. Example: 2, 5, 8, 11, 14... has a_1 = 2, d = 3. The common difference can be negative or zero.
Arithmetic sequence: common difference d. Formula: a(n) = a(1) + (n−1)d.
Arithmetic series sum: S(n) = n/2 · (a(1) + a(n)) or S(n) = n/2 · (2a(1) + (n−1)d).
Arithmetic with Complex Numbers: Add/subtract real parts and imaginary parts separately. Multiply using FOIL, remembering i² = -1. Divide by multiplying by the conjugate of the denominator.
Association in categorical data does NOT imply causation — the same rule applies as with numerical data.

Assumptions for Linear Regression: Linearity (relationship is linear), independence (observations independent), normality (residuals approximately normal), equal variance (residuals have constant spread for all x).

At height h from the center, the cross section of a sphere of radius r is a circle with area π(r² − h²). This matches a cylinder of radius r with a cone of radius r removed — hence V(sphere) = V(cylinder) − V(cone) = πr²(2r) − ⅓πr²(2r) = (4/3)πr³.

Average Cost: If fixed cost is F and variable cost per unit is v, total cost C(n) = F + vn for n units. Average cost A(n) = C(n)/n = (F + vn)/n. This is a rational function with a horizontal asymptote at y = v.
Ax² + Bxy + Cy² + Dx + Ey + F = 0

Basic Trig Equations: sin x = a, cos x = a, tan x = a for |a| ≤ 1 (sine/cosine). Find reference angle, then use quadrant information to find all solutions. General solutions include ± 2πn or ± πn depending on function.
Bayes' Theorem: P(A|B) = P(B|A) · P(A) / P(B). Relates conditional probabilities in both directions. Used in medical testing: P(disease|positive test) involves test accuracy.
Binomial Coefficient: C(n,r) is the coefficient in binomial expansion (a+b)^n. Pascal's triangle shows these coefficients. C(n,0) = 1, C(n,n) = 1, C(n,r) = C(n,n-r).
Binomial theorem (introduction): (a + b)ⁿ can be expanded using patterns from Pascal's Triangle.
Break-Even Problems: Find where revenue equals cost. Set profit function equal to zero or set revenue equal to expense. The intersection point is the break-even point.
Change of Base Formula: log_b(x) = log(x)/log(b) = ln(x)/ln(b). Allows computing any logarithm using calculator (which typically has log base 10 and natural log).
Check r² (coefficient of determination) — closer to 1 means a better fit.

Checking Reasonableness: Does the solution make sense in context? For quantities, expect positive values. For rates, check if they're realistic. Always verify by substituting into the original problem.

Checking Solutions: Exponential equations: check by substituting. Logarithmic equations: verify that arguments are positive (domain restriction of logarithm). Extraneous solutions can appear when applying properties.
Checking Solutions: Substitute the x and y values into both original equations. The solution is correct if both equations are satisfied.
Circle: (x - h)² + (y - k)² = r². Center (h, k), radius r. Equation of tangent line perpendicular to radius at point of tangency. Distance formula finds radius given center and point.

Combinations vs Permutations: Choosing 3 from {A,B,C,D,E}: combinations give ABC, ABD, ABE, ACD, ACE, ADE, BCD, BCE, BDE, CDE (10 total). Same objects in different order → same combination but different permutations.
Combinations: Selection of objects where ORDER DOESN'T MATTER. C(n,r) = n!/(r!(n-r)!), also written "n choose r". Always C(n,r) ≤ P(n,r). Example: choosing 3 of 5 books: C(5,3) = 5!/(3!2!) = 10.
Combinations: order does NOT matter. C(n, r) = n! / (r!(n−r)!).
Combine transformations: e.g., y = −2(x − 3)² + 1 is a reflection, stretch by 2, right 3, up 1.

Combining Transformations: y = a(x-h)² + k applies all transformations. The order matters: horizontal/vertical shifts, then stretches/compressions. Reading transformations from vertex form is straightforward.
Common Application Types: Mixture problems: combining items at different rates. Distance problems: using distance = rate × time. Investment problems: combining different interest rates.
Comparing Functions: Linear functions grow fastest for small x, but exponential eventually dominates. Logarithmic functions grow slowest. For very large x: exponential > linear > logarithmic.
Completing the square rewrites ax² + bx + c in vertex form a(x − h)² + k.
Complex Conjugates: For a + bi, the conjugate is a - bi. When a polynomial with real coefficients has a complex zero, its conjugate is also a zero. Complex zeros come in conjugate pairs.

Complex Fractions: Fractions with fractions in numerator/denominator. Simplify by finding LCM of all denominators and multiplying numerator and denominator by it. Or treat numerator and denominator separately, simplify, then divide.
Complex Numbers: Form a + bi where a and b are real and i² = -1. Real part is a, imaginary part is b. Complex numbers extend our number system to allow nth roots of any polynomial.
Complex numbers provide an algebraic framework for transformations (rotation = multiplication by e^(iθ), dilation = multiplication by a scalar).
Components: Objective function: what we're maximizing/minimizing (P = ax + by). Constraints: limitations on variables (system of inequalities). Feasible region: all points satisfying all constraints.

Concentration and Mixture: If x grams of substance are diluted in y milliliters of liquid, concentration = x/y g/mL. Adding more liquid increases denominator, decreasing concentration. These become rational function models.

Conditional Probability: P(A|B) = P(A and B) / P(B). Probability of A given B has occurred. Denominator is not 100% but P(B). Example: P(roll 3 | die is even) = P(3 and even) / P(even) = 0 / (1/2) = 0.

Confidence Intervals: Range estimate for population parameter. 95% confidence interval means 95% of such intervals would contain true parameter. General formula: estimate ± (critical value) × (standard error). For mean: x̄ ± t* × s/√n.

Conic Sections Definition: Curves formed by intersecting plane with a cone. Circle: plane perpendicular to axis. Ellipse: plane at angle. Parabola: plane parallel to side. Hyperbola: plane cuts both nappes.

Continuous Compound Interest: A = Pe^{rt} is the continuous version of interest compounding. As compounding frequency increases, (1+r/n)^{nt} → e^{rt}. This is the most efficient interest calculation.
Convergence Condition: Geometric series converges if and only if |r| < 1 (r is strictly between -1 and 1). The sum S = a/(1-r) is a finite value. When |r| ≥ 1, partial sums increase without bound.
Cooling Law: T(t) = T_s + (T_0 - T_s)e^{-kt} describes temperature decrease. T_s is surrounding temperature, T_0 is initial temperature, k is cooling rate. Temperature approaches T_s asymptotically.
Correlation does not imply causation — just because two variables are correlated does not mean one causes the other.
Correlation means two variables have a statistical association — they change together in a predictable way.
Cosine Function: y = cos(x) has amplitude 1, period 2π. Key points: (0, 1), (π/2, 0), (π, -1), (3π/2, 0), (2π, 1). Shifts sine left by π/2: cos(x) = sin(x + π/2).
Coterminal Angles: Angles that differ by multiple of 360° (or 2π radians). Example: 30°, 390°, -330° are coterminal. Coterminal angle formula: θ + 360n° or θ + 2πn.
Counting Principle: if event A has m outcomes and event B has n outcomes, there are m × n total outcomes.
Cross-Multiplication: For equations like A/B = C/D, cross-multiply: AD = BC. This shortcut is valid and often simpler than finding LCD, but still check for extraneous solutions.
Cross-multiply: 15x = 60 → x = 4
De Moivre's Theorem: [r cis θ]ⁿ = rⁿ cis(nθ). Power simplification. Example: (1 + i)¹⁰. Finding nth roots: z^(1/n) = r^(1/n) cis((θ + 2πk)/n) for k = 0, 1, ..., n-1.
Decibel Scale: dB = 10 log(I/I_0) for intensity. Logarithmic scale compresses wide ranges. Small dB changes represent large intensity changes.
Decision Rule: If p-value < α, reject H₀ (statistically significant). If p-value ≥ α, fail to reject H₀ (insufficient evidence). Common α: 0.05 or 0.01.

Degree Measure: Full rotation = 360°. Right angle = 90°. Straight angle = 180°. Acute angle < 90°, obtuse angle 90° < angle < 180°. Angle measured counterclockwise from standard position (positive ray of x-axis).
Dependent Events: Events A and B are dependent if P(A then B) = P(A) · P(B|A) where P(B|A) is conditional probability of B given A occurred. Drawing without replacement creates dependency.

Derivatives Parametrically: dy/dx = (dy/dt)/(dx/dt). Not dy/dx obtained by implicit differentiation. Acceleration vector: a(t) = (d²x/dt², d²y/dt²). Velocity vector: v(t) = (dx/dt, dy/dt), speed |v(t)| = √((dx/dt)² + (dy/dt)²).

Descartes' Rule of Signs: Count sign changes in p(x) to estimate positive roots. Count sign changes in p(-x) to estimate negative roots. Number of real roots of each type is at most this count and differs by an even number.
Difference of Squares: a² - b² = (a+b)(a-b). Recognizable as two perfect squares with a minus sign between them. Can apply multiple times for higher powers.
Difference of squares: a² − b² = (a + b)(a − b).
Difficulty: How hard topic is & how well they explained it
Dilation centered at the origin with scale factor k: (x, y) → (kx, ky)
Divide radicals: √a / √b = √(a/b). Rationalize the denominator if needed.
Dividing: Multiply by the reciprocal: (P/Q) ÷ (R/S) = (P/Q) × (S/R). Simplify as with multiplication. Important: the reciprocal's denominator is S, which must be non-zero.
Domain and Range: Domain is all real numbers. Range depends on the vertex and direction. If opens up: range is [k, ∞). If opens down: range is (-∞, k].

Domain and Range: The domain is the set of all possible input values, while the range is the set of all possible output values. Restrictions occur when denominators are zero or when values are under even-root radicals.
Double Angle Formulas: sin 2x = 2 sin x cos x. cos 2x = cos² x - sin² x = 2 cos² x - 1 = 1 - 2 sin² x. tan 2x = 2 tan x / (1 - tan² x).
Drawing with replacement → independent. Drawing without replacement → dependent.
Each Angle = (n − 2) × 180° / n
Each exterior Angle of a regular Polygon = 360° / n.
Eliminating Parameter: Solve one equation for t, substitute into other. Example: x = 2t + 1, y = t² → t = (x-1)/2 → y = ((x-1)/2)². Check for domain/range restrictions preserved in conversion.
Ellipse: (x-h)²/a² + (y-k)²/b² = 1 (horizontal) or swap a, b (vertical). Center (h, k). Major axis length 2a, minor axis 2b. Foci at distance c where c² = a² - b². Eccentricity e = c/a < 1.
Enclose the region in a rectangle. Generate random points. The area ≈ (hits inside region / total points) × area of rectangle.

End Behavior: Determined by the degree and leading coefficient. For very large/small x, the polynomial behaves like its leading term ax^n. Odd degree with positive a: goes from bottom-left to top-right. Negative a: top-left to bottom-right.
Energy cannot be created or destroyed — it can only be transformed from one form to another or transferred between objects.
Energy flows through ecosystems in one direction: from the sun → producers → consumers → decomposers.
Equivalent Expressions: P(x)/Q(x) and [P(x) × R(x)]/[Q(x) × R(x)] are equivalent rational expressions (same domain restrictions). Use this to find common denominators or create equivalent forms.

Euler's Formula & Applications: e^(iθ) = cos θ + i sin θ. Complex exponential connects trig functions. Applications in physics: wave equations, oscillations, quantum mechanics. Solving z^n = 1 gives nth roots of unity equally spaced on unit circle.
Events are dependent if the outcome of one affects the other. P(A and B) = P(A) × P(B|A).
Events are independent if the outcome of one does NOT affect the other. P(A and B) = P(A) × P(B).
Exact Values: Common angles have known exact values. sin(0) = 0, sin(π/6) = 1/2, sin(π/4) = √2/2, sin(π/3) = √3/2, sin(π/2) = 1. Cosine values reverse for complement.
Example: 1/x + 1/2 = 1 → LCD = 2x → 2 + x = 2x → x = 2.
Example: 2x + 3 = 11 → 2x = 8 → x = 4. Always check by substituting back.
Example: 2ˣ = 8 → 2ˣ = 2³ → x = 3.
Example: 5.2 km = 5.2 × 10³ m = 5200 m
Example: 6x² + 9x = 3x(2x + 3). Set each factor equal to 0.
Example: A blueprint has scale 1 in : 4 ft. A room measures 3.5 in on the blueprint. Actual length = 3.5 × 4 = 14 ft.
Example: A person standing 50 m from a building looks up at the top with an Angle of elevation of 60°. Height = 50 × tan 60° = 50√3 ≈ 86.6 m.
Example: For x² + 4x + 5 = 0, D = 16 − 20 = −4 < 0 → no real solutions.
Example: If two sides are 5 and 11, then the third side must be between 11 − 5 = 6 and 5 + 11 = 16: 6 < c < 16.
Example: If two similar rectangles have a scale factor of 3:5, and the smaller has perimeter 24, the larger has perimeter 24 × (5/3) = 40.
Example: In a right Triangle with Angle 35° and hypotenuse 10:
Example: In △ABC with AB = 5, BC = 8, AC = 6, the angles from smallest to largest are: ∠C < ∠B < ∠A (Angle opposite the shortest side is smallest).
Example: Water (H2O) -> ice, liquid water, steam - same atoms, different arrangements.
Example: x² + 5x + 6 = (x + 2)(x + 3) because 2 × 3 = 6 and 2 + 3 = 5.
Example: −2x > 6 → x < −3 (flip the sign because you divided by −2).
Examples: Solve d = rt for r → r = d/t. Solve A = ½bh for h → h = 2A/b.
Examples: x + 5 = 12 → x = 7; 3x = 18 → x = 6.
Exponential Decay: When 0 < b < 1, f(x) = ab^x decays. The smaller b, the faster decay. Graph approaches 0 from above as x → ∞. Common form: f(x) = a(1/2)^{x/h} where h is half-life.
Exponential Functions: Form f(x) = ab^x where a ≠ 0, b > 0, b ≠ 1. Base b determines growth (b > 1) or decay (0 < b < 1). The graph is always positive and approaches 0 as x → -∞ (for growth).
Exponential Growth: When b > 1, f(x) = ab^x grows exponentially. The larger b, the faster the growth. Doubling time or tripling time describes how long for the function to double or triple in value.
Exponential growth increases slowly at first, then rapidly — it eventually outpaces any linear or polynomial growth.
Exponential regression uses technology to find the best-fit exponential equation y = a · bˣ for a data set.

Extraneous Solutions: When clearing denominators, we might introduce solutions that make the original denominator zero. These are extraneous. Always verify: substitute back and check if any denominator becomes zero.
FOIL: First, Outer, Inner, Last — used for (a + b)(c + d).
Factor x² + bx + c: find two numbers that multiply to c and add to b.
Factorial: 0! = 1 (definition), 1! = 1, 2! = 2, 3! = 6, 4! = 24, etc. Grows very fast. Used in permutation and combination calculations.
Factoring Trinomials: For ax² + bx + c, find two numbers that multiply to ac and add to b. Use these to split the middle term, then factor by grouping. Alternatively, use the AC method.
Finance: Compound interest A = P(1 + r/n)^{nt}. Continuous compounding: A = Pe^{rt}. Present value given future value. Investment problems using logarithms to solve for time.
Finding Key Points: y-intercept by setting x=0. x-intercepts (zeros) by factoring or using the quadratic formula. Axis of symmetry is x = h. Use symmetry to find additional points on the parabola.
Finding Probabilities: P(X ≤ a) requires standardizing to Z, then using table. P(a c) = 1 - P(X ≤ c).
Finding Restrictions: Set denominator equal to zero: Q(x) = 0. Solve for x. These x-values are excluded from the domain. Write in domain restriction notation.

Finding Sum: First, identify first term a and common ratio r. Check |r| < 1 for convergence. If convergent, S = a/(1-r). Useful for repeating decimals: 0.333... = 3/10 + 3/100 + 3/1000 + ... = (3/10)/(1 - 1/10) = 1/3.

Finding Terms: Given a_1 and r, find any term using a_n = a_1 · r^{n-1}. Common ratio: r = a_{n+1}/a_n. Handle negative ratios (alternating sign sequences). To insert geometric means between two terms, compute appropriate r and generate intermediates.

Finding Terms: Once a_1 and d known, any term can be found: a_n = a_1 + (n-1)d. To find d: d = (a_m - a_k)/(m - k). To insert arithmetic means between two terms, find common difference and generate intermediate terms.

Finding Zeros: Combined with the Rational Root Theorem, these help identify possible zeros quickly. Test candidates using synthetic division (factor theorem). List factors and corresponding zeros systematically.
Finding the Vertex: Use x = -b/(2a) to find the x-coordinate of the vertex. Substitute into f(x) to find the y-coordinate. Vertex (h,k) is the extreme point of the parabola.
For a right Triangle with an acute Angle θ:
For any convex polyhedron: V − E + F = 2, where V = vertices, E = edges, F = faces.
For ax² + bx + c (a ≠ 1), use the AC method: find two numbers that multiply to ac and add to b, then factor by grouping.
Fractals often have a non-integer dimension. The Sierpinski Triangle has dimension ≈ 1.585, meaning it is more than a Line (1D) but less than a filled region (2D).
Function Notation: f(x) represents the output of function f when the input is x. This replaces the older y = notation and makes it clear which variable is the input.
Functions are relations that assign exactly one output to each input. A function f(x) can be evaluated by substituting a value for x and simplifying.

Fundamental Counting Principle: If first event has m outcomes and second event has n outcomes, total outcomes is m × n. Extends to multiple events: multiply all possibilities. Example: 3 appetizers, 4 mains, 2 desserts → 3 × 4 × 2 = 24 meals.
Fundamental Identities: sin² x + cos² x = 1 (Pythagorean). tan x = sin x / cos x. cot x = cos x / sin x. sec x = 1 / cos x. csc x = 1 / sin x.

Fundamental Theorem of Algebra: A degree n polynomial with complex coefficients has exactly n zeros (counting multiplicity), all lying in ℂ (complex numbers). Real polynomials may have real or complex zeros.
Geometric Sequence: Sequence with constant ratio r between consecutive terms. a_n = a_1 · r^{n-1}. Example: 2, 6, 18, 54... has a_1 = 2, r = 3. Each term is r times the previous term.
Geometric sequence: common ratio r. Formula: a(n) = a(1) · r^(n−1).
Geometric series sum (finite): S(n) = a(1)(1 − rⁿ)/(1 − r), where r ≠ 1.
Given two triangles with angles 40°, 60°, 80° and 40°, 60°, 80°: the triangles are similar by AA (two pairs of angles match).

Graph Characteristics: Passes through (1, 0) because log_b(1) = 0. Passes through (b, 1) because log_b(b) = 1. Increasing if b > 1, decreasing if 0 < b < 1. Slow growth: logarithmic growth is much slower than exponential.
Graph solutions on a number line: use an open circle for , and a closed circle for ≤ or ≥.
Graphical Solutions: Graph each line and find intersection point(s). One intersection = unique solution. Parallel lines = no solution. Same line = infinitely many solutions.
Graphing Linear Equations: Plot the y-intercept, then use slope to find another point. Slope indicates rise over run: positive slopes go ↗, negative slopes go ↘.
Graphing on Number Line: Mark the boundary point. Shade left of the point if x < or x ≤, right if x > or x ≥. Use open circle for strict inequalities, closed for ≤/≥.
Greatest Common Factor (GCF): Always check for a common factor in all terms first. Factor out the GCF; this is factoring by grouping applied to all terms.
Half of an Equilateral Triangle. If the short leg (opposite 30°) = a, then:
Half-Life: Time required for quantity to reduce to half its value. After one half-life, 50% remains. After two half-lives, 25% remains (50% of 50%). n half-lives: (1/2)^n fraction remains.

Holes in the Graph: If numerator and denominator share a factor (x-c), both have a zero at c. This cancels to a hole (removable discontinuity), not an asymptote. Find the y-coordinate by evaluating the simplified function at x = c.
Horizontal Asymptotes: Determine by comparing degrees of numerator and denominator. If degree of numerator denominator degree: no horizontal asymptote.
Horizontal Shifts: f(x-h) shifts the parabola h units right (h>0) or left (h<0). Vertex moves from (h₁,k) to (h₁+h,k). The axis of symmetry shifts accordingly.
Horizontal translation: f(x − h) shifts the graph right h units; f(x + h) shifts it left.

Hypothesis Testing: Test H₀ (null hypothesis) vs Hₐ (alternative). Type I error: reject H₀ when true (α significance level). Type II error: fail to reject H₀ when false (β). p-value: probability of observing data as extreme given H₀ is true.
Identify the conic by comparing A and C: if A = C → circle; if A ≠ C but same sign → ellipse; if A or C = 0 → parabola; if A and C have opposite signs → hyperbola.
If BD bisects ∠B in △ABC, then AD/DC = AB/BC.
If DE ∥ BC in △ABC, where D is on AB and E is on AC, then: AD/DB = AE/EC.
If Point D is in the interior of ∠ABC, then m∠ABD + m∠DBC = m∠ABC.
If a ≠ 1, divide the entire equation by a first.
If event A has m outcomes and event B has n outcomes, then A followed by B has m × n outcomes.
If p → q is true and p is true, then q must be true.
If p → q is true and q → r is true, then p → r is true.
If two angles are congruent, the third must also be congruent (since angles sum to 180°). Once all angles match, the sides are automatically proportional.
If two similar figures have a scale factor of a : b, then the ratio of their areas is a² : b².
If x-values in a table are not consecutive, compute the ratio using r = (y₂/y₁)^(1/(x₂−x₁)).
In any Triangle, you can order the sides from shortest to longest and the angles from smallest to largest — these orderings match:
In right △ABC with altitude CD to hypotenuse AB (where D is the foot):
In spherical geometry, "lines" are great circles. There are no parallel lines — every pair of great circles intersects at two points.
In y = a · bˣ, a is the initial value and b is the growth/decay factor.
In △ABC and △DEF: AB = DE = 8, BC = EF = 6, and ∠B = 70° while ∠E = 50°.
Independent Events: Events A and B are independent if P(A and B) = P(A) · P(B). One event doesn't affect the other. Examples: coin flips, die rolls.
Induction Examples: Prove Σ_{i=1}^{n} i = n(n+1)/2. Prove geometric sequence formula a_n = a_1 · r^{n-1}. Prove statements about divisibility: 3^n - 1 is always divisible by 2.
Inequalities use the symbols: (greater than), ≤ (less than or equal), ≥ (greater than or equal).
Infinite Geometric Series: a + ar + ar^2 + ar^3 + ... where |r| < 1 converges to a/(1-r). If |r| ≥ 1, the series diverges (sum is infinite or undefined). Tests for convergence depend on common ratio.
Interpreting Results: Discriminant tells us about roots without solving. Helps predict the graph: two x-intercepts, one x-intercept, or no x-intercepts.
Interpreting Solutions: Pick a test point in the shaded region to verify it satisfies both inequalities. The entire shaded region represents the solution set.
Inverse Problem: Given probability, find the value. Example: Find c such that P(X < c) = 0.90. Use Z-table in reverse to find z, then solve X = μ + z·σ.
Inverse Trigonometric Functions: y = arcsin x, arccos x, arctan x give principal values in restricted ranges. sin⁻¹(x) ∈ [-π/2, π/2], cos⁻¹(x) ∈ [0, π], tan⁻¹(x) ∈ (-π/2, π/2).

Key Features: Vertex: minimum (a>0) or maximum (aAxis of symmetry: divides parabola in half. y-intercept: at (0,c). x-intercepts: where parabola crosses x-axis (roots).
Key Properties: log_b(bx) = 1, log_b(1) = 0, log_b(b) = 1. Inverse relationship: b^{log_b(x)} = x and log_b(b^x) = x. Domain: x > 0 only.
Key identities: (a + b)² = a² + 2ab + b², (a − b)² = a² − 2ab + b², (a + b)(a − b) = a² − b².
Law of Cosines: c² = a² + b² - 2ab cos C. Use for SAS or SSS. Relates all three sides to an angle. Special case: when C = 90°, reduces to Pythagorean theorem.
Law of Sines: a/sin A = b/sin B = c/sin C. Use when you have ASA, AAS, or SSA (ambiguous). In triangle with angles A, B, C and opposite sides a, b, c respectively. Solves non-right triangles.
Limitations: Dimensional analysis cannot determine dimensionless constants (like 2π) or distinguish between quantities with the same dimensions (work vs torque).
Linear: y = mx + b. Exponential: y = a · bˣ.
Logarithm Definition: y = log_b(x) means b^y = x. Logarithm is the inverse of exponential. Base b > 0, b ≠ 1. Common base: log_10(x) = log(x). Natural base: log_e(x) = ln(x).
Logarithmic Functions: f(x) = log_b(x). These are inverse functions of f(x) = b^x. Domain: x > 0. Range: all real numbers. Graph has vertical asymptote at x = 0.
Logarithmic Properties: log_b(xy) = log_b(x) + log_b(y) (product rule). log_b(x/y) = log_b(x) - log_b(y) (quotient rule). log_b(x^n) = n·log_b(x) (power rule).

Mathematical Induction: Proof technique for statements about all positive integers. Two steps: (1) Base case: prove statement true for n = 1. (2) Inductive step: assume true for n = k, prove it's true for n = k+1. Proves infinitely many cases with finite work.
More random samples → better estimate. Error decreases proportionally to 1/√n, where n is the number of samples.
Multiplication & Division in Polar Form: Product: z₁z₂ = r₁r₂ cis(θ₁ + θ₂). Quotient: z₁/z₂ = (r₁/r₂) cis(θ₁ - θ₂). Real and imaginary parts multiply in polar but angles add/subtract.
Multiply radicals: √a · √b = √(ab). Example: √3 · √12 = √36 = 6.

Multiplying Polynomials: Use FOIL for binomials or the distributive property for general cases. FOIL: First, Outer, Inner, Last. For longer polynomials, multiply each term in the first by every term in the second.
Natural Logarithm: ln(x) = log_e(x). Its inverse is y = e^x. Properties identical to all logarithms with base e. ln(e) = 1, ln(1) = 0, e^{ln(x)} = x, ln(e^x) = x.

Normal Distribution: Bell curve, symmetric around mean μ. Characterized by mean and standard deviation σ. Z-score: (X - μ)/σ standardizes to N(0,1). Empirical rule: 68% within 1σ, 95% within 2σ, 99.7% within 3σ.
Oblique Asymptotes: For n(x)/d(x) where deg(n) = deg(d) + 1, divide to get quotient q(x) + remainder. The asymptote is y = q(x). As x → ±∞, the function approaches this line.

Operations with Functions: Functions can be combined through addition, subtraction, multiplication, and division. Composition of functions (f ∘ g)(x) = f(g(x)) means apply g first, then apply f to the result.

Optimization: Perimeter problems that lead to area quadratics. Garden fence problems: find dimensions that maximize area with fixed perimeter. Area = length × width, then substitute using the constraint.
Outliers in a box plot are typically shown as individual points beyond 1.5 × IQR from Q1 or Q3.
P(A and B) = P(A) × P(B | A)
P(A or B) = P(A) + P(B) − P(A and B)

Parabola & Hyperbola: Parabola: (y-k)² = 4p(x-h) (horizontal) or (x-h)² = 4p(y-k) (vertical). Vertex (h, k), focus, directrix p units away. Hyperbola: (x-h)²/a² - (y-k)²/b² = 1 (horizontal) or reversed. Asymptotes: y - k = ±(b/a)(x - h). Eccentricity e = c/a > 1 where c² = a² + b².
Parallel lines are coplanar lines that never intersect. Symbol: ∥ (e.g., Line l ∥ Line m).
Parallelogram → Rectangle (right angles), Rhombus (equal sides) → Square (both)

Parametric Representation: Describe curve using x = f(t), y = g(t) where t is parameter. Often t represents time. Example: x = 3cos(t), y = 3sin(t), t ∈ [0, 2π] traces circle x² + y² = 9. Eliminates parameter to get Cartesian equation.
Perfect square trinomial: a² + 2ab + b² = (a + b)² and a² − 2ab + b² = (a − b)².
Period and Frequency: T = 2πr/v, f = 1/T, ω = 2πf.
Periodicity & Signs: Trigonometric functions repeat every 2π radians. Signs vary by quadrant: Q1 all positive, Q2 sin positive, Q3 tan positive, Q4 cos positive.

Permutations: Arrangement of objects where ORDER MATTERS. n! = n × (n-1) × ... × 1. Permutations of n objects taken r at a time: P(n,r) = n!/(n-r)!. Example: arranging 3 of 5 books: P(5,3) = 5!/2! = 60.
Permutations: order matters. P(n, r) = n! / (n−r)!

Point-Slope Form: y - y₁ = m(x - x₁) is useful when you know a point on the line and the slope. This form can be rearranged to slope-intercept form.

Polar Form of Complex Numbers: z = a + bi = r(cos θ + i sin θ) = r cis θ where r = |z| = √(a² + b²) and θ = arg(z). Conversion: a = r cos θ, b = r sin θ. θ is angle from positive real axis, measured counterclockwise.
Population Growth: P(t) = P_0 e^{rt} (continuous) or P(t) = P_0(1+r)^t (discrete). r is growth rate. Doubling time: 0.693/r (continuous). Applications: bacteria, human population, viral spread.
Power Reduction: sin² x = (1 - cos 2x)/2. cos² x = (1 + cos 2x)/2. Used to simplify expressions and solve equations.
Power: P = IV = I²R = V²/R.

Practical Applications: Loan amortization uses series formulas. Monthly payment computed using present value of annuity. Stock dividend accumulation. Pendulum oscillation amplitudes (geometric decay). Recursive sequences define many real systems.
Probability Definition: P(event) = (favorable outcomes)/(total outcomes) for equally likely outcomes. Ranges from 0 (impossible) to 1 (certain). 0% to 100%. Complement rule: P(not A) = 1 - P(A).
Probability is always between 0 and 1: 0 ≤ P(E) ≤ 1.
Probability with Combinations: Many problems use C(n,r) to count favorable outcomes. Example: probability of 2 heads in 3 coin flips: C(3,2)/2^3 = 3/8. Lottery odds: C(49,6) total combinations.
Productivity and Diminishing Returns: Models like P(x) = kx/(1 + ax) where productivity increases then levels off. The horizontal asymptote k/a represents maximum productivity as x → ∞.
Profit and Revenue: Profit P(x) = Revenue - Cost = R(x) - C(x). Often quadratic. Find maximum profit at the vertex. Break-even points are where P(x) = 0 (setting revenue equal to cost).

Projectile Motion: Height h(t) = -16t² + v₀t + h₀, where v₀ is initial velocity and h₀ is initial height. The maximum height occurs at the vertex. Set h(t) = 0 to find when the object hits the ground.
Properties of Exponents: b^{x+y} = b^x · b^y, b^{xy} = (b^x)^y, b^{-x} = 1/b^x. These properties allow solving exponential equations algebraically when bases are equal.

Quadratic Functions: Functions of the form f(x) = ax² + bx + c where a ≠ 0. The graph is a parabola (U-shaped curve). The coefficient a determines the direction: a > 0 opens upward, a < 0 opens downward.
Quadratic regression finds the best-fit equation y = ax² + bx + c for data that follows a parabolic pattern.
Quantum Tunneling: A particle can pass through a potential barrier even if its energy is less than the barrier height — there is a nonzero probability of being found on the other side.
Radian Measure: Based on arc length. 1 radian = arc length equals radius. Full rotation = 2π radians = 360°. Conversion: radians = degrees × π/180°, degrees = radians × 180°/π.
Radioactive Decay: N(t) = N_0 e^{-μt} where λ is decay constant. Relates to half-life: half-life = ln(2)/λ. Used for carbon dating and nuclear material calculations.
Ratio of sides: 1 : 1 : √2
Ratio of sides: 1 : √3 : 2
Rational Expressions: Fractions with polynomials in numerator and denominator. Form P(x)/Q(x) where Q(x) ≠ 0. Domain excludes values making the denominator zero (restrictions).
Reading the Result: Quotient has degree one less than the dividend. If remainder is 0, (x-c) is a factor. If remainder is non-zero, R(x) = R and result is Q(x) + R/(x-c).

Real-World Applications: Navigation and bearings: angle measured from north. Height problems: angle of elevation/depression. Projectile motion: initial velocity at angle θ. Harmonic motion: position = A cos(ωt + φ).
Reference Angles: Acute angle between terminal side and x-axis. Used to find trig values for any angle. Reference angle always between 0° and 90°.
Reflection: −a reflects over the x-axis; b^(−x) reflects over the y-axis.
Reflection: −f(x) reflects over the x-axis; f(−x) reflects over the y-axis.

Regression Line Equation: \hat{y} = b_0 + b_1 x. Slope b_1 = r × (s_y/s_x), y-intercept b_0 = \bar{y} - b_1 \bar{x}. Confidence intervals for slope: slope ± t* × SE(b_1). Hypothesis tests on correlation using t-statistic.
Relationship: E = −dV/dr. The field points in the direction of decreasing potential.
Relativistic Energy: E² = (pc)² + (mc²)². For a photon (m = 0): E = pc.
Right-Hand Rule: Point fingers in the direction of velocity (or current), curl toward B — thumb points in the direction of force (for positive charges).
Sample Space & Events: Sample space is all possible outcomes. Event is subset of sample space. Experiment can produce random outcomes. Example: die roll has sample space {1,2,3,4,5,6}.

Series: Sum of terms in a sequence. Arithmetic series: a_1 + a_2 + ... + a_n. Geometric series: a_1 + a_1r + a_1r^2 + ... + a_1r^{n-1}. Infinite series: sum of infinitely many terms (may or may not converge).
Sets of three positive integers that satisfy a² + b² = c²:

Setting Up Synthetic Division: Write coefficients of the dividend in descending order; include 0 for missing terms. The constant c (from x - c) goes as the divisor on the left. Use a special box/table format.
Shuffle Score: 0 Restart Pause Fuel Bar Ready to Fly? Answer correctly to fly up against the moving ladder!
Sigma notation (Σ) provides a compact way to write a series: Σ from i=1 to n of a(i).
Since ∠B > ∠E and the two pairs of sides are equal, the Hinge Theorem tells us AC > DF.
Sine Function: y = sin(x) has amplitude 1, period 2π. Oscillates between -1 and 1. Passes through origin (0, 0). Key points: (π/2, 1), (π, 0), (3π/2, -1), (2π, 0).

Sketching the Parabola: Plot the vertex and axis of symmetry first. Plot the y-intercept and its symmetric point. Find and plot x-intercepts if they exist. Use the shape (determined by a) to sketch a smooth U or inverted-U curve.
Slope = rise/run = (y₂ − y₁)/(x₂ − x₁). It measures the steepness and direction of a line.
Solutions on Intervals: Specify interval like [0, 2π] to list finite. For x ∈ [0, 2π], sin x = 1/2 has solutions x = π/6, 5π/6. Check domain restrictions (tan x undefined at π/2, etc.).
Solving Exponential Equations: If bases are equal, exponents are equal: b^m = b^n → m = n. If bases aren't equal, take logarithm of both sides. Use logarithm properties to simplify.
Solving Logarithmic Equations: Use exponential (inverse) form: if log_b(x) = k, then x = b^k. Properties of logarithms can condense or expand terms before converting to exponential form.

Solving Quadratic Inequalities: Inequalities like ax² + bx + c > 0. First solve the corresponding equation ax² + bx + c = 0 to find boundary points. These boundary points divide the number line into intervals.
Special Patterns: Perfect square trinomials: a² + 2ab + b² = (a+b)². Sum/difference of cubes: a³ + b³ = (a+b)(a²-ab+b²). Factoring by grouping for four-term polynomials.
Special Sums: Σ_{i=1}^{n} 1 = n, Σ_{i=1}^{n} i = n(n+1)/2, Σ_{i=1}^{n} i^2 = n(n+1)(2n+1)/6, Σ_{i=1}^{n} i^3 = [n(n+1)/2]^2. These formulas allow closed forms for many series.

Standard Normal Distribution: Mean = 0, standard deviation = 1. Denoted Z ~ N(0,1). Z-table gives cumulative probability P(Z ≤ z). Any normal random variable can be converted to standard form: Z = (X - μ)/σ.
Standard and Vertex Forms: Standard form: f(x) = ax² + bx + c. Vertex form: f(x) = a(x-h)² + k, where (h,k) is the vertex. Vertex form makes the parabola's features immediately visible.
Standard form: y = ax² + bx + c. Steps: (1) Find the axis of symmetry x = −b/(2a). (2) Find the vertex by substituting. (3) Plot the y-intercept and its mirror point. (4) Plot additional points.
Step-by-Step Process: (1) Multiply equation(s) to make coefficients opposites. (2) Add the equations. (3) Solve for the remaining variable. (4) Substitute back to find the other variable.

Step-by-Step Process: (1) Solve one equation for one variable (choose the easiest). (2) Substitute the expression into the other equation. (3) Solve the resulting one-variable equation. (4) Back-substitute to find the other variable.
Steps: (1) Solve the related equation ax² + bx + c = 0 to find boundary points. (2) Test intervals. (3) Write the solution.
Sum and Difference Formulas: sin(A ± B) = sin A cos B ± cos A sin B. cos(A ± B) = cos A cos B ∓ sin A sin B. tan(A ± B) = (tan A ± tan B) / (1 ∓ tan A tan B).

Sum of Arithmetic Sequence: S_n = (n/2)(a_1 + a_n) = (n/2)(2a_1 + (n-1)d). Gauss's formula: sum of first n positive integers is n(n+1)/2. Sum is always the average of first and last term, times the count.
Sum of Geometric Sequence: If r ≠ 1: S_n = a_1(1 - r^n)/(1 - r) = a_1(r^n - 1)/(r - 1). If r = 1: S_n = na_1. The formula works even with negative r.
Sum/Difference of cubes: a³ + b³ = (a + b)(a² − ab + b²); a³ − b³ = (a − b)(a² + ab + b²).

Summation Notation: Σ symbol denotes sum. Σ_{i=1}^{n} a_i means a_1 + a_2 + ... + a_n. Index i is the summation variable. Lower limit (below Σ) and upper limit (above Σ) define the range. Rules: Σ c·a_i = cΣ a_i, Σ(a_i + b_i) = Σ a_i + Σ b_i.
Synthetic division is a shortcut when dividing by (x − c). Use only the coefficients.
Systems with Parameters: Solve systems where coefficients may contain variables or parameters. Determine when solutions exist and predict how parameters affect the solution.
Tangent Function: y = tan(x) = sin(x)/cos(x). Undefined at x = π/2, 3π/2, ... (where cos = 0). Vertical asymptotes at these points. Period = π.
Telescoping Series: Series where consecutive terms cancel: Σ (a_i - a_{i+1}) = a_1 - a_{n+1}. Useful for partial fractions decomposition.

Test Point Method: Mark the roots on a number line. Test one x-value in each interval in the original inequality. If true, the entire interval is part of the solution. If false, the interval is excluded.

The Discriminant: Δ = b² - 4ac. This value determines the nature and number of solutions. If Δ > 0: two distinct real solutions. If Δ = 0: one repeated real solution. If Δ < 0: two complex conjugate solutions.

The Elimination Method: Multiply one or both equations by constants so that one variable has opposite coefficients. Add the equations to eliminate that variable, leaving one equation with one unknown.
The Fundamental Theorem: The maximum or minimum occurs at a corner point (vertex) of the feasible region. Find all vertices and test each in the objective function.
The Number e: e ≈ 2.71828... defined as lim_{n→∞} (1+1/n)^n. The natural base appears in continuous growth and compound interest. Also appears as the base of natural logarithm.
The Quadratic Formula: x = [-b ± √(b²-4ac)] / (2a). This solves any quadratic equation ax² + bx + c = 0 directly without factoring or completing the square.

The Remainder Theorem: When polynomial p(x) is divided by (x-c), the remainder equals p(c). This allows quick evaluation: instead of substituting into a complex polynomial, perform synthetic division and read the remainder.
The Remainder Theorem: when P(x) is divided by (x − c), the remainder equals P(c).
The Substitution Method: Solve one equation for a variable, then substitute that expression into the other equation. This reduces the system to one equation with one variable.
The absolute value of a number is its distance from zero: |x| ≥ 0 always.
The complement of event E: P(not E) = 1 − P(E).
The correlation coefficient r (or r²) indicates how well the model fits. Closer to ±1 (or 1) means a better fit.
The decay factor b = 1 − r, where r is the decay rate.
The discriminant is the expression under the square root in the quadratic formula: D = b² − 4ac.
The distance between two points (x₁, y₁) and (x₂, y₂) in the coordinate Plane is:
The explicit formula is: a(n) = a(1) + (n − 1)d, where a(1) is the first term.
The explicit formula is: a(n) = a(1) · r^(n−1).
The geometric mean of two positive numbers a and b is x = √(ab). It is the positive number x such that a/x = x/b.
The graph approaches the x-axis but never touches it — the x-axis is a horizontal asymptote.
The growth/decay rate r = b − 1. Growth: r > 0. Decay: r < 0.
The interquartile range (IQR) measures the spread of the middle 50% of data: IQR = Q3 − Q1. It is resistant to outliers.

The negation of a statement p (written ~p or ¬p) has the opposite truth value. If p is true, then ~p is false, and vice versa.
The quadratic formula: x = (−b ± √(b²−4ac)) / (2a) solves any equation ax² + bx + c = 0.
The range is the difference between the maximum and minimum values: Range = Max − Min.
The scale factor is the ratio of corresponding side lengths. If △ABC ~ △DEF with scale factor k, then AB/DE = BC/EF = AC/DF = k.
The slant height ℓ, height h, and radius r are related by: ℓ² = h² + r².

The sum of the exterior angles of any convex Polygon (one at each vertex) is always 360°, regardless of the number of sides.
The sum of the measures of the interior angles of a Triangle is 180°.
The variance is the square of the standard deviation: σ² = Σ(x − x̄)² / n.
The vertex is the highest or lowest point. The axis of symmetry is x = −b/(2a).
The ± means there are potentially two solutions.
Three-dimensional versions of scale drawings. Same principles apply — all linear dimensions are scaled by the same factor.
To add unlike radicals, simplify first: √12 + √27 = 2√3 + 3√3 = 5√3.
To find an exponential equation from a table: (1) Find the common ratio r. (2) Find the initial value a (when x = 0). (3) Write y = a · rˣ.
To solve |x| < a: write −a < x < a (AND compound inequality).
To solve |x| = a (where a ≥ 0): set up two equations: x = a or x = −a.
Transformations: y = A sin(B(x - C)) + D. A is amplitude (vertical stretch). B affects period (new period = 2π/B). C is horizontal shift. D is vertical shift. Tangent has period π, not 2π.

Transformations: y = log_b(x - h) + k shifts the graph. h shifts right (h > 0) or left. k shifts up (k > 0) or down. Vertical asymptote shifts to x = h. The reflection over the line y = x gives y = b^x.
Transformers: V₂/V₁ = N₂/N₁. Step-up (N₂ > N₁) increases voltage; step-down decreases it.
Trigonometric Ratios: sin θ = y, cos θ = x, tan θ = y/x (on unit circle). Also cot θ = x/y, sec θ = 1/x, csc θ = 1/y. SOHCAHTOA helps remember right triangle ratios.
Two angles are complementary if the sum of their measures is 90°.
Two angles are congruent if they have the same measure. Notation: ∠A ≅ ∠B.
Two angles are supplementary if the sum of their measures is 180°.
Two lines are perpendicular (⊥) if they intersect to form right angles (90°).
Two lines are perpendicular if they intersect at right angles (90°). The shortest distance from a Point to a Line is always along the perpendicular segment.
Two segments are congruent (≅) if they have the same length. Notation: AB ≅ CD means segment AB is congruent to segment CD.
Two solids are congruent if they have exactly the same shape and size — all corresponding measurements are equal.
Two triangles are congruent if all their corresponding sides and corresponding angles are congruent. When listing congruent triangles, the order of vertices matters — it shows which parts correspond.

Two-Way Tables (Contingency Tables): Organize data for two categorical variables. Cell entries are counts. Marginal distributions shown in totals. Conditional probabilities calculated by dividing cell by row/column total.
Types of Asymptotes: Vertical: where denominator = 0. Horizontal: determined by degree comparison. Oblique (slant): when numerator degree = denominator degree + 1. Find by polynomial long division.
Types of Discontinuities: Removable: hole from cancelled factors. Non-removable/infinite: vertical asymptote. Jump: piecewise functions with different limits from left and right.
Types of Systems: Consistent and independent: exactly one solution. Consistent and dependent: infinitely many solutions. Inconsistent: no solution.
Understanding Applications: These theorems avoid long division. Instead of dividing p(x) by (x-c), calculate p(c) directly. If p(c) = 0, we know (x-c) divides evenly.

Unit Circle: Circle with radius 1, center at origin. Point on circle: (cos θ, sin θ). Angles measured counterclockwise from (1, 0). Complete circle = 2π radians. Special angles: 0, π/6, π/4, π/3, π/2, etc.
Use dashed lines for and solid lines for ≤ or ≥.
Use inverse trig functions: θ = sin⁻¹(opp/hyp), θ = cos⁻¹(adj/hyp), θ = tan⁻¹(opp/adj).
Use the same inverse operations as with regular equations — just treat the other variables as constants.
Using the Formula: Substitute a, b, c correctly (watch signs!). Simplify the discriminant first. The ± symbol means we find two values. Always check if the radicand is negative.

Using the Theorem: List all factors of the constant term and leading coefficient. Form possible rational roots. Test each using synthetic division (or p(c) = 0). This is efficient for polynomials degree 3 and higher.
Vector Basics: Vector has magnitude and direction: v = ⟨a, b⟩ = ai + bj. Magnitude |v| = √(a² + b²). Unit vector: u = v/|v|. Zero vector 0 = ⟨0, 0⟩. Position vector from origin to point (a, b).

Vector Equations & Applications: Line: r(t) = r₀ + tv (parametric form). Projectile motion: r(t) = (vcos α)t i + ((vsin α)t - ½gt²) j. Work: W = F·d. Physics problems model forces and motion as vectors.

Vector Operations: Addition: ⟨a₁, b₁⟩ + ⟨a₂, b₂⟩ = ⟨a₁+a₂, b₁+b₂⟩ (parallelogram law). Scalar multiplication: c⟨a, b⟩ = ⟨ca, cb⟩. Dot product: u·v = |u||v|cos θ where θ is angle between vectors. Also u·v = a₁a₂ + b₁b₂.
Vertex and Axis of Symmetry: The vertex is the turning point. The axis of symmetry is the vertical line x = -b/(2a) passing through the vertex. The parabola is symmetric about this line.
Vertex form: y = a(x − h)² + k, where (h, k) is the vertex.

Vertical Asymptotes: Occur at x-values where denominator is zero (and not cancelled by numerator). These are "forbidden" x-values. Graph approaches these lines but never touches them. Plot as dashed vertical lines.
Vertical Shifts: f(x) + k shifts the parabola k units up (k>0) or down (k<0). Vertex moves from (h,k₁) to (h,k₁+k). The shape doesn't change, only the position.
Vertical Stretches and Compressions: a·f(x) multiplies the y-values by a. If |a|>1, the parabola stretches (gets narrower). If 0<|a|<1, it compresses (gets wider). If a<0, the parabola flips.
Vertical stretch/compression: a·f(x) — if |a| > 1, vertical stretch; if 0 < |a| < 1, vertical compression.
Vertical translation: f(x) + k shifts the graph up k units; f(x) − k shifts it down.
When both sides can be written with the same base: if bˣ = bʸ, then x = y.
When to Use Substitution: This method works best when one variable has a coefficient of 1 or -1, making it easy to isolate. If all coefficients are complex, elimination might be easier.

Writing Solutions: Use inequality notation for intervals. Solution might be x b (two rays), or a < x < b (one interval), or no solutions, or all real numbers. Express using interval notation or set notation.
m∠inscribed = ½ × m(intercepted arc)
pH and pKa: pH = -log[H⁺] in chemistry. Logarithmic scale where pH 7 is neutral. pH 7 is basic. Henderson-Hasselbalch equation uses logarithms.
t-test vs z-test: Use z-test when σ known and n large. Use t-test when σ unknown (more common). t-distribution has fatter tails than normal, especially for small n.
